subject: Re: [junit] JUnit 4 restructuring

messageBody:
Hi Elliotte,

All good points, and I'm in general agreement with everything you say below.

Again, all I was trying to do was to fight against the dogmatic "never
expose a protected method if you don't have to". As you rightfully point out
in your message below, this mailing-list is comprised of experts who have a
good grasp of the compromises involved in making such decisions, and if one
of them decides that there is some potential to be gained by exposing a
protected method, they should follow their instinct and go ahead, even if
that potential is unseen at the time of writing and, more importantly, even
if it goes again the Agile Principles.

That's called intuition, and listening to it once in a while is a duty,
along with questioning absolute statements such as "YAGNI".

--
Cedric
http://testng.org



On 11/2/05, Elliotte Rusty Harold <elharo@...> wrote:
>
> Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
>
> > You don't know that, because you never heard from them. And for all you
> > know, all these potential users chose to use a different library than
> yours
> > because they had more freedom there.
>
> Perhaps, but I don't think so. I not only pay pretty close attention to
> what users are asking me. I listen to what users are asking from my
> competition. (fringe benefit of open source and open development).
> Unless they're a lot of people working on their own XML frameworks in
> their basements, there's just not that much need for extending the
> framework beyond what I provide. Even in frameworks that allow a lot
> more extensibility of this type (DOM comes to mind) people don't
> actually seem to take advantage of that possibility.
>
> Inheritance is vastly overrated. The number of people who actually want
> to change a class's behavior is extremely small in most cases.
>
>
> > And even if you could know this number for sure, just accept that other
> > people have different experiences than you do (among which, most of the
> > people who are participating in this thread, it seems).
>
>
> Actually, I'd turn that back on you. Different people have different
> experiences and different needs, but these experiences and needs are not
> equal in numbers or importance. The programmers who hang out on mailing
> lists like this one (especially this one) are a very highly
> self-selected group. They are in many ways much more theoretically and
> abstractly inclined than 90% of working developers. Most programmers who
> write books about programming and who design and publish libraries are
> really way beyond the typical working developer. Not a surprise: some
> programmers are experts in programming and some are experts in insurance
> or financial derivatives or shock wave modeling or something else. We
> can't all be experts in everything. But these mailing lists attract the
> meta-programmers: the programmers who are experts in programming.
>
> Guess what? We're weird, even among programmers. We are much more
> comfortable with abstraction than even other typical programmers. Design
> patterns, factory methods, interfaces, inheritance, polymorphism, and
> anything beyond simple data encapsulation is way beyond the comfort
> level of most actual programmers. A library designed for ease of use by
> a typical programmer needs to focus on the 90% rather than the 10%. If
> you gauge the audience for a tool by the programmers who hang out in
> forums like this one, you're going to miss the vast body of programmers
> who don't.
>
> What you are in effect arguing is that you don't want to be held back by
> the needs of the many. You can safely use extra extension points, and
> therefore they should be there. But most programmers don't feel this
> way. Most of them can at least safely ignore the extra methods. They
> probably won't shoot themselves in the foot even if we give them plenty
> of bullets. However the sheer complexity of adding all these extra
> extension points make the classes so much harder to use that the cost to
> the many outweighs the benefits to the few.
>
> Sometimes we do need subclassing and extra extension points, but not
> that many and not that often; even when considering only the most
> abstractly inclined of programmers. Extension points are not without
> cost. There's is or should be a significant hurdle to be jumped before
> adding a new published method. Even if the method is inherently useful
> and has no corresponding problems, it still needs to be useful enough.
> It's not enough that one or a few people might use a method. It needs to
> be pretty clear that large percentage of a library's users are going to
> take advantage of the feature, or that it be extremely important to a
> smaller but still sizeable percentage.
>
> We can argue about exactly where to put the line: how useful to how many
> people does a method need to be before we add it. However that number is
> quite a bit higher then 1. It is certainly higher than 0. That a feature
> might someday be used by someone, but we aren't quite sure who or when,
> is not sufficient grounds to include it. There needs to be a positive
> decision that a feature will be useful before it's added. Featuritis is
> as damaging to APIs as it is to applications.
>
>
